## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Spitzer, STEREO A, Mars)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-07-28T18:38:23Z
## Message ID: 20170728-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2017-07-28T05:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~574 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 38 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -136/4 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2017-07-28T05:36:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Spitzer, STEREO A, and Mars (glancing blow).  The leading edge of the CME will reach Spitzer at 2017-07-31T16:21Z and STEREO A at 2017-07-31T07:34Z, and the flank of the CME will reach Mars at 2017-08-03T04:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2017-07-28T05:36:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170728_113000_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170728_113000_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170728_113000_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170728_113000_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170728_113000_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170728_113000_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170728_113000_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170728_113000_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STB_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

[1] http://iswawiki.gsfc.nasa.gov/wiki/index.php/Glossary/Heliospheric_Earth_Equatorial_coordinates

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-07-28T15:24:21Z
## Message ID: 20170728-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-07-28T14:50Z.  The electron flux has been elevated for the last four days, previous crossing of the threshold occurred on 2017-07-24T15:05Z (see notification ID 20170724-AL-003) and on 2017-07-26T14:35Z (see notification ID 20170726-AL-001).

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2017-07-20T12:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-07-28T14:50:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 19, 2017 - July 25, 2017 - CORRECTED
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-07-27T12:11:15Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-07-19T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-07-25T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170727-7D-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs, 1 R-type CME(see details below). The CMEs with starting times 2017-07-23T01:36Z and 2017-07-23T04:39Z launched very close to each other and merged into one CME propagating away from the sun, with very high speed. Simulations carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center indicated that the combinded CME would impact STEREO B, missions at Mars, the Dawn spacecraft and have a flank impact at STEREO A (see notifications 20170723-AL-003 and 20170724-AL-002). An interplanetary shock was detected by STEREO A at 2017-07-24T18:00Z, with the total magnetic field reaching > 60nT and B_z > 50 nT (note, real-time STEREO A solar wind data has data gaps, so the actual values could be even higher).


Geomagnetic activity was at low to moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.
Kp=5 was reached during the synoptic period 2017-07-22T09:00Z - 2017-07-22T12:00Z, which was associated with a high speed stream arriving at Earth on 2017-07-20T12:00:00.


The 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-07-24T15:05Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream arrival described above (see notifications 20170724-AL-001 and 20170724-AL-003).  


A solar energetic particle event was detected by STEREO A: the flux of 13-100 MeV protons exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2017-07-23T10:19Z (see notifications 20170723-AL-001 and 20170723-AL-002). This event was associated with the fast CMEs mentioned above (2017-07-23T01:36Z and 2017-07-23T04:39:00Z).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES was at background levels for most of the reporting period. At around 2017-07-25T12:00Z a slight increase was measured, most likely due to the fast CMEs mentioned above, although the flux levels remained below the threshold.



Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been high this week with the impact of the fast CMEs heading towards STEREO A, B, Mars and Dawn and the SEP event also connected to this CME. Missions at Earth are expected to have been impacted by the significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  


CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed


Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2017-07-20T18:24Z     ~620            C               121/2                 28                          STEREO A, SOHO                    
2017-07-23T01:36Z     ~944            C               154/13                33                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2017-07-23T04:39Z     ~2271           R               170/-4                46                          STEREO A, SOHO                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-07-26T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-08-01T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity are expected to be low for the upcoming week. The Earth facing side of the solar disk shows no visible sunspots, EUV images currently show 2 faint active regions, that are quiescent. The active region that had the fast CMEs this week will still be on the far-side, it continues to show some activity and there is some chance of additional eruptions. STEREO A EUV images also show several small coronal holes, which will result in increased solar wind speed in the next few days at STEREO A.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CMEs update (Dawn, Mars, STEREO B, STEREO A)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-07-24T16:11:44Z
## Message ID: 20170724-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Update on CMEs with IDs 2017-07-23T01:36:00-CME-001 and 2017-07-23T04:39:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20170723-AL-003).  Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may impact Dawn.  The leading edge of the CMEs will reach Dawn at 2017-07-28T07:35Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Previous simulations also estimate that the CMEs may affect Mars, STEREO B, and STEREO A (glancing blow).  The leading edge of the CMEs will reach Mars at 2017-07-25T21:44Z, the leading edge will reach STEREO B at 2017-07-24T18:32Z and the flank may reach STEREO A at 2017-07-24T22:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

CME parameters are (C-type):

1: Start time of the event: 2017-07-23T01:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~944 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 33 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 154/13 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2017-07-23T01:36:00-CME-001


2: Start time of the event: 2017-07-23T04:39Z.

Estimated speed: ~2271 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 46 deg.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 12, 2017 - July 18, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-07-20T00:29:47Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-07-12T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-07-18T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170720-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period with one M-class flare (see list below).  There were four C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with the Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=6 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-07-16T12:00Z-15:00Z, 2017-07-16T18:00Z-21:00Z and 2017-07-17T15:00Z-18:00Z.  The increased Kp on 2017-07-16 was associated with the 2017-17-14T01:36Z CME arrival detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2017-07-16T05:14Z (see notifications 20170714-AL-003, 20170714-AL-004, 20170716-AL-003, and 20170716-AL-004).  Simulations carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center indicated that the CME arrival also caused that the magnetopause boundary separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit around 2017-07-16T11:23Z (see notifications 20170716-AL-001 and 20170716-AL-002).  The geomagnetic activity on 2017-07-17 was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream at the tail end of the CME arrival on 2017-07-16.  Solar wind speeds reached values of >650 km/s on 2017-07-16 and remained elevated for several days.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-07-16T15:45Z.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the combined effects of the CME and the coronal hole high speed stream arrivals described above (see notifications 20170717-AL-001 and 20170717-AL-002).  

The flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2017-07-14T09:00Z.  This solar energetic particle event detected by GOES was associated with the M2.4 class flare that peaked at 2017-07-14T02:09Z (see details below) and the 2017-07-14T01:36Z CME (see notifications 20170714-AL-001 and 20170714-AL-002).  

The energetic proton flux of 13-100 MeV protons detected at STEREO A was at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate this week due the the solar energetic particle event and the increased energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-07-19T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-07-25T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming reporting period.   Active region 12665 has already rotated off the west limb as seen from SDO imagery, but could still produce coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  A minor disturbance is possible on 2017-07-20 to 07-21 from a large coronal hole located in the Sun's northern hemisphere.

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-07-16T15:45Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the CME with ID 2017-07-14T01:36:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20170714-AL-003 and 20170714-AL-004).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-07-16T15:45:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 

The CME with ID 2017-07-14T01:36:00-CME-001 has also resulted in a geomagnetic storm with a Kp index equal to 6 during 2017-07-16T12:00Z to 2017-07-16T15:00Z and from 2017-07-16T18:00Z to 2017-07-16T21:00Z.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-07-14T18:47:43Z
## Message ID: 20170714-AL-004
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on the CME with ID 2017-07-14T01:36:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20170714-AL-003). 

Based on heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Out of 48 ensemble members (see notes section), 47 (97%) indicate impact at NASA missions near Earth. Ensemble simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2017-07-16T04:38Z and 2017-07-17T04:36Z (average arrival 2017-07-16T16:51Z). The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 74% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2017-07-14_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX062/20170714_013600_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX062_anim_tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2017-07-14_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX062/20170714_013600_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX062_arrival_Earth.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2017-07-14_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX062/20170714_013600_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX062_Earth_stack.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2017-07-14_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX062/20170714_013600_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX062_probabilistic_Kp_forecast_wdist.gif

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling at SWRC is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2017-07-14_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX062/Detailed_results_20170714_013600_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX062.txt

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2017-07-14T01:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~750 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 49 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 40/-9 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2017-07-14T01:36:00-CME-001

 
Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that this CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2017-07-16T21:42Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-5 (below minor to minor).

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2017-07-14T01:36:00-CME-001):

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 05, 2017 - July 11, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-07-12T21:55:23Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-07-05T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-07-11T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170712-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period with 1 M-class flare (see list below), several C-class flares and numerous B-class flares, most of them originating from active region 12665.   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest Kp=5 value occurred the synoptic periods of 2017-07-09T00:00Z-2017-07-09T03:00Z and 2017-07-09T09:00Z-2017-07-09T12:00Z. This minor increase in geomagetic activity was caused by a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around late 2017-07-08.

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream starting around 2017-07-05 for which solar wind speed reached values of 500-600 km/s.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-07-12T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-07-18T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low to moderate in the upcoming week.  Active region 12665 is rotating to the western hemisphere, where is favorably located to produce a missions near Earth impacting coronal mass ejection.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. The activity could be slightly enhanced by the arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-07-16.

## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 28, 2017 - July 04, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-07-05T21:05:03Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-06-28T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-07-04T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170705-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period with 1 M-class flare (see list below).  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that the CME (S-type) starting on 2017-06-28T15:24Z would impact Spitzer (glancing blow) around 2017-07-02T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours).  The simulation also indicated that the CME (S-type) starting on 2017-06-28T16:24Z CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth around 2017-07-02T19:30Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20170629-AL-001).  There was a weak CME arrival detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-07-01T16:26Z attributed to the 2017-06-28 CME.  

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2017-07-02T06:00Z-09:00Z. This slight enhancement in geomagnetic activity was associated with the CME arrival detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 described above.  

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-07-01.  Solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.
